message_1: A sample of cesium-137 was found to have an initial activity of 1.2 x 10^5 Bq. Calculate the activity of the sample after 10 years, given that the half-life of cesium-137 is 30.17 years. Round your answer to two significant figures.
message_2:
To calculate the activity of the sample after 10 years, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

A = A0 * (1/2)^(t/T)

where A is the final activity, A0 is the initial activity, t is the time elapsed (10 years), and T is the half-life of the substance (30.17 years for cesium-137).

A = (1.2 x 10^5 Bq) * (1/2)^(10/30.17)

A ≈ (1.2 x 10^5 Bq) * (1/2)^0.3316

A ≈ (1.2 x 10^5 Bq) * 0.7935

A ≈ 9.522 x 10^4 Bq

Rounding to two significant figures, the activity of the sample after 10 years is approximately 9.5 x 10^4 Bq.
